title: UK weather forecast: Deep floods to bring travel chaos before gales and snow hit
text:

Deep flooding is expected in Britain today before gales and snow lash the country.

The Met Office issued an amber warning saying transport chaos and power cuts were likely in parts of the UK.

Now weather experts say gales are possible as a cold front pushes across the country.

Snow is forecast in the Scottish Highlands this weekend before high pressure builds up.

This will lead to cold, clear night skies that drive down temperatures.

Met Office meteorologist Steven Keates said: “A cold front will move across the country later on Saturday and this will bring a marked change in temperatures compared to the start of the weekend.

“There will be blustery showers and the risk of gales in the north on Sunday, there is a chance that some of these showers will turn wintry especially over high ground.

(Image: Aled Llywelyn)

(Image: MET office)

“It is going to feel markedly colder, especially across the southeast after this cold front moves across bringing temperatures down from mid-double figures to around 9C to 12C.

“We are going to be a bit below average in terms of temperatures into the start of next week.

“Skies will be clear so it is going to be chilly, we are also going to see winds coming in from the north and the east. There will be a risk of frosts in the morning and some early fog.”

Today's amber weather warning covers large parts of south Wales until 11am.

The Met Office says flooding and transport disruption are likely.

Meanwhile less serious yellow weather warnings remain in effect in other parts of the country until 3pm.

These cover the rest of Wales, the Midlands, parts of northern England and the south west.

(Image: PA)

The Government's Flood Information Service has 13 flood warnings where "immediate action is required", across Yorkshire, the Midlands, and into Wales.

Early on Saturday morning, Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Service said crews had been sent to people who had driven into flood water.

The service tweeted: "Large volumes of flood water in North Devon are making driving conditions hazardous. Fire & Police have attended a number of people who have driven into floodwater. Drivers are asked to respect road closures, not diverting to minor roads which are more treacherous. Avoid travel."

Humberside Police said a number of roads were impassable due to flooding and urged drivers to avoid the area around the B1246 at Warter.

Meanwhile, a burst of "polar maritime air" is also expected to bring colder temperatures to northern parts of the nation on Saturday, before hitting the rest of the country on Sunday and into next week.

This is expected to bring colder weather, with the first widespread frost of the season anticipated over the weekend, as well as a dusting of snow on higher ground.

UK five-day weather forecast

Today

Heavy rain clearing slowly southeastwards from England and Wales. Colder conditions with sunny spells following, but also scattered showers, these frequent in the northwest. Windy in the south at first, and also in the far north.

Tonight

Rain finally clearing the southeast around midnight, to leave a dry night with clear periods and colder than recently. Windy with showers in the north and gales on some coasts.

Sunday

Dry with sunny periods in central and southern areas. Windy with occasional showers in the north, the showers turning wintry over high ground in northern Scotland later.

Outlook for Monday to Wednesday

Largely settled with sunny spells for most. Just the odd shower in the east and northeast. Rather cold with overnight frosts. Possibly turning more unsettled from the southwest midweek.
description: The Met Office has issued an amber weather warning today before a cold front pushes its way across the country
